title: Roadmap vs Sales Escalation
description: Sales wants a feature for a big prospect that doesn't fit the current roadmap. Engineering is already at capacity and your existing users are asking for other improvements.

choices.text: Say no to sales for now, backing it up with data from current users and the agreed roadmap priorities.
Agree to build the sales feature next, reshuffling the roadmap to try to close the deal quickly.
Offer a compromise: a lighter version of the feature or a workaround, and revisit a full solution if the deal closes.

title: User Research vs Shipping
description: You have a strong feature idea but very limited user research. Engineering has a gap next sprint and could build it quickly, but design wants more discovery.

choices.text: Pause and run proper discovery with several users, even if it means missing the next sprint window.
Greenlight a minimal version now and plan to learn from real usage data.
Split the sprint: some engineers build a spike/prototype while you and design do scrappy parallel research.

title: Tech Debt Pushback
description: Engineering insists that a release should be mostly tech-debt work. Stakeholders see no visible value in this and are pressuring you for shiny features.

choices.text: Back engineering fully and commit the sprint to tech debt, translating the benefits into language stakeholders understand.
Compromise by carving out a small portion of the sprint for tech debt and the rest for stakeholder-visible features.
Ask engineering to squeeze tech debt into the background while focusing the sprint on visible wins.

title: Conflicting Feedback: Power Users vs New Users
description: Power users want advanced controls that would complicate the UI, while new users are struggling with the basics.

choices.text: Prioritize simplifying the core flows for new users, postponing advanced features.
Ship advanced options quickly for power users and accept extra complexity as the cost of retention.
Design a progressive setup: keep the default simple but add discoverable advanced controls for those who need them.

title: Experiment That Failed
description: You pushed for an experiment that didn’t move the metrics. Leadership is asking whether it was a waste of time.

choices.text: Frame it as a clear learning, using the data to explain what you now know and how it changes the roadmap.
Quietly move on and avoid drawing attention to the failed experiment.
Push for more iterations on the same idea, arguing that it wasn’t given a fair chance.

title: Saying No to the Founder
description: The founder suggests a pet feature based on a single conversation. You know it doesn’t fit the strategy or current data.

choices.text: Push back directly with data and explain why it doesn’t fit the current priorities.
Agree to fit a small version into the roadmap soon to keep alignment high.
Offer to test the idea quickly with a lightweight prototype or user interviews before committing engineering time.

title: Ownership vs Delegation
description: You’re stretched thin across multiple squads. One team keeps asking you to join every meeting and make every decision.

choices.text: Stay deeply involved with that team and accept that other areas will move slower.
Empower a lead within the team to own more decisions and step back from most meetings.
Create clearer decision frameworks and rituals so teams can move with less of your direct involvement.
